form.definition: noun E or e is the fifth letter of the English alphabet.

dictionary.entry:
Ei: <for sense 2; for sense 1, varies as> /\times,0\ist, gl/
abbreviation for many words. The most common examples are east and English.
noun In music, E is the third note in the scale of C major.

form.definition: determiner If you refer to each one in a group, you are thinking of them individually or one by one. You'll need to complete a separate immigration form for each child in your family.
pronoun Each may refer to each one in a group. They had all wanted the job, but each was disappointed.
adverb If things cost so much each, they cost that much for each one. The large oranges are fifty cents each.
adjective If you are eager to do something, you are keen and impatient to do it. You want to do it very much. I was eager to leave at once, but the others wanted to wait.
adjective If you are eager about something, you are excited about it. Bill enjoyed seeing the children's eager faces as he gave out presents at the Christmas party.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eagerness adverb eagerly

form.definition: noun Your ears are the two parts of your body attached to each side of your head which allow you to hear sounds.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun The ear of a cereal plant is the top part on which the grain grows.

good ear If people say you have a good ear for something, they mean you are good at noticing and remembering sounds that you hear. Antonia's pronunciation of Chinese is excellentshe must have a good ear. John's a great mimic, with a really good ear for accents.

play by ear If you play something by ear, you make decisions as you go along, without planning. It also means to play music without referring to the written music. We haven't decided yet what to do on Saturday night. Sandra wants to wait till then and play it by ear. Andrew can listen to any song and play it by earhe's very musical.
noun The eardrum is a membrane in your ear. It separates the external ear from the part of the ear that is inside your body.

dictionary.entry:
early`@:li: (adverb and adjective forms earlier, earliest
adverb If something happens early, it happens towards the beginning of a period of time. I like to get up early, as soon as it's light. Let's meet early next weekhow about Monday or Tuesday?
adjective The early part of something is the part near the beginning. I'll call round in the early eveningsay about six? She must be in her early thirties. ...art of the early 20th century. 2a adverb If something happens early, it happens before the time that is arranged or expected. I arrived five minutes early for the appointment. George died earlyhe was only fifty.
adjective If something is early, it is before the time that is arranged or expected. Bill took early retirement. You're early! It's only seven o'clock.
as early as As early as a particular time means from that time onwards, even though it might seem surprising. You can come as early as six o'clock if you like. The signs were there as early as last year, but it's only now that the problem has become obvious.

form.definition: verb If you earn money, you receive it as payment for a job you have done. I earned $25 babysitting yesterday. She earns $50 000 a year.
verb If someone or something earns something, they get it and they deserve it. You have to earn the respect of your staff. Her first film earned several prizes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun earnings Her earnings were not enough to cover her expenses.noun earner I'm the main earner in our household.

form.definition: adjective If someone is earnest, they are serious and sincere. He's an earnest young man, and very reliable. Is she earnest about wanting to study, or is it just a passing fancy?
in earnest (a) If you do something in earnest, you do it seriously and intensively. I'd read a bit before, but I only started studying the subject in earnest last year.
(b) If you say something in earnest, you really mean it. He said he'd lend us his car, but I don't know if he was in earnest.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb earnestly

form.definition: noun An earphone is a small electronic device which you put over or in your ear so that you can listen to something in private. I don't want to disturb you with this music, so I'll put on my earphones.
noun An earring is a piece of jewellery that you attach to your ear. My husband gave me some lovely gold earrings for my birthday.

noun We call the planet we live on earth. You can spell this with a capital: Earth. The earth moves around the sun once each year. The rocket returned safely to earth. Mars is the nearest planet to Earth.
noun The soil or dirt in the ground, especially when it's good enough to grow plants, is also called earth. Heap plenty of earth around the carrots as you plant them.
noun The earth is one of the three wires in household electrical cords. It is covered in green and yellow rubber. This fridge is dangerous because it hasn't got an earth.
form.note: ... SEE ALSOthe contrasting words live and neutral.

form.definition: cost the earth If you say that something costs the earth, you mean that it is very expensive. Putting in a new bathroom doesn't have to cost you the earth.
on earth The expression on earth is used for emphasis. What on earth are you doing? I don't know how on earth he managed to do it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb earth This fridge isn't earthed properly.

form.definition: noun Earthenware is plates and pots made of baked clay.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective earthenware

form.definition: noun An earthquake is a shaking of the ground. It is caused by the crust of the earth moving or slipping. The earthquake in Newcastle caused damage to many buildings.
verb If you ease something, you make it less severe or painful. This aspirin should ease the pain. The extra income will ease their financial problems.
verb If you ease something somewhere, you move it very carefully and gently. I eased the shoe off her badly swollen foot. Ease the cover back on the lounge without forcing it.

at ease (a) If you feel at ease, you feel comfortable and relaxed. It took me several weeks to feel at ease in the new house. Sit down, make yourself at ease. I ask a few general questions first, to put the candidates at ease.
(b) If soldiers are commanded to stand at ease, they stand with their legs apart and their hands behind their backs.
ease off If something eases off, it becomes less or it stops. The rain has eased off now. Ease off teasing him nowyou'll make him cry.
ease up If you ease up on something, you do it less or you stop doing it. You've worked hard enough todayyou'd better ease up for a while.
with ease If you do something with ease, you do it easily. It is not too hard for you. She passed her exam with ease.
noun An easel is a stand for a painting that an artist is working on, or for a blackboard.
noun The east is the direction where the sun rises. The wind was blowing from the east.
noun The east of a country or region is the part which is most towards the east.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective easterly ...easterly winds.adjective eastern We were travelling to the eastern states.

form.definition: noun Easter is a Christian festival commemorating the death of Jesus Christ and his being raised to life again. Are you going anywhere for the Easter break?
adverb Eastward means 'toward the east'. The river flows eastward.
adjective If something is easy, it is not difficult to understand or to do. I found the exam quite easy. The beginners' course may be too easy for you. Spending money is easy!
adjective If something is easy, there is not much to worry about. There is very little pain or trouble. She has an easy time of ither husband does most of the housework. He hasn't had an easy life.
adjective If someone says they are easy, they mean they do not mind what other people decide to do. You choose the videoI'm easy.
go easy If you go easy, you do not demand or use too much. You are reasonable. Go easy on the kidsthey're really tired tonight. Go easy with that moneyit's got to last till Thursday.
take it easy If you take it easy, you relax. You do not work hard. You do not get tense or angry. I'm taking it easy this weekendI need a break. Take it easy, you guysno need for a fight.
verb If you eat something, you put it in your mouth, chew it and swallow it. She's always eatingno wonder she's so fat.
verb If you eat at a certain time, you have a meal then. What time shall we eat tonight? Have you eaten yet?
eat away If something eats something else away, it erodes it or destroys it slowly. The sea had eaten away the rock on the cliff face. The rust was eating the metal away.
eat out If you eat out you go out to a restaurant for a meal instead of eating at home. I can't afford to eat out except on special occasions.
eat up If something eats up something else, it uses a large amount of it. His work eats up a lot of his weekend. People are reluctant to buy programs that eat up too much disc space.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eater My cat's a fussy eater.

form.definition: noun The eaves of a house or building are the lower edges of the roof which hang over and beyond the walls. I had a tiny bedroom, up under the eaves.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat house.

form.definition: verb If you eavesdrop, you secretly listen to someone else's conversation. When I got a crossed line I couldn't resist eavesdropping.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eavesdropper

form.definition: verb When the tide ebbs, the level of the sea becomes lower on the shore line. This happens twice a day. You can also say that the tide goes out.
verb If something ebbs or ebbs away, it goes away gradually, or becomes weaker. His strength is ebbingI don't think he'll last the night. I could feel my resolve ebbing. The warmth ebbed out of me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ebb Our finances are at a low ebb.

form.definition: adjective If someone is eccentric, they behave in a different way to most other people. They are rather strange and odd. He's not crazy, just a bit eccentric. She's got some very eccentric ideas. The decor reflected the eccentric taste of the previous owners.
noun An eccentric is someone who continually behaves in a way that's different to other people, especially if that behaviour is thought to be strange or odd.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eccentricity (eccentricities) You'll get used to her little eccentricities.

form.definition: abbreviation for electrocardiograph. This is a machine which tests the electrical activity of the heart.
abbreviation for electrocardiogram. This is the picture or record made by an electrocardiograph. It is used in diagnosing heart illness. My doctor sent me for an ECG.[qr

dictionary.entry:
echidna@`kIdn@
noun An echidna is an Australian animal which is covered with spines. Although it is a mammal, its young hatch from eggs. The echidna is on the five cent coin.

form.definition: noun An echo is a sound that comes back to you because the sound waves are reflected off a hard surface. The children shouted into the tunnel and then laughed at the echo of their voices.
verb If something echoes, it sounds loud because the surroundings are quiet or empty. The choir's singing echoed through the church. His footsteps echoed in the darkness.
verb If you echo someone else, you say the same thing as they have already said. She's got no opinions of her ownshe just echoes the boss. I should like to echo the point that Ferenc made.

noun In an eclipse of the sun, the moon passes between the earth and the sun, blocking the sun's light to the earth. In an eclipse of the moon, the earth passes between the moon and the sun so that the moon is in the earth's shadow.
form.note: ... NOTEAn eclipse of the sun is called a solar eclipse. An eclipse of the moon is called a lunar eclipse.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone or something eclipses someone or something else, you mean that they are much better, so that the other thing or person hardly gets noticed. I got a good mark in the exam but Bill eclipsed us allhe did brilliantly.
noun If you study ecology, you study how living things work and live together in the earth's environment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ecologist

form.definition: noun If you study economics, you study the way trade works and how money is created and distributed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun economist

dictionary.entry:
economy@`kOn@mi:economies 1 noun An economy is the way a country's resources, trade, business and finances are managed and organised. Australia's economy relies heavily on agriculture and mining. The economy is entering
noun Economy is also being careful with money or supplies so that you don't use them up too fast. With a bit of economy I can manage quite well on my pension. If you use the detergent with economy it should last for months.
... WORD FAMILYadjective economic ...economic growth.adjective economical The larger packet is more economical.verb economise (<or> economize) When I lost my job I was forced to economise by eating out less often.

form.definition: noun Eczema is an itchy skin disease often caused by allergy.
noun The edge of something is its border or outside boundary. Water spilled over the edge of the table onto the floor. Come backyou're too close to the edge of the cliff.
noun An edge is also the line that you see where two things meet. The children were playing on the sand at the water's edge.
noun The edge of a knife or axe is the sharp part of the blade.
verb If you edge somewhere, you go there cautiously in a series of small movements. I edged out onto the window ledge. He was edging nervously toward the door. Excuse me, could I just edge past?
on edge If you are on edge, you are nervous, tense and upset. I've been on edge all day, waiting to hear from him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective edgy (edgier, edgiest) I felt tired and edgy.

form.definition: adjective If something is edible, it is fit to be eaten. My steak was so tough it was barely edible.

verb If you edit a book, newspaper, or magazine, you prepare its contents so that it can be printed and published. You make corrections and organise the material. I volunteered to edit the newsletter.
verb If you edit a film, or a television or radio program, you select the content and organise the various sections. The interview with the President was heavily edited.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun editor

form.definition: noun An edition is one printing of a book, magazine or newspaper. The early edition of the paper contained mistakes which were corrected in the afternoon edition. They're planning a second edition of the dictionary.
noun An editorial is an article written by the editor of a publication which gives his or her own opinion on a certain subject. Today's paper has a very strong editorial on the economy.
noun Education is the process of teaching people skills and knowledge which they need in different subjects.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb educate Sophie was educated in France.

form.definition: adjective If something is eerie, it is strange or weird and makes you feel a bit afraid. The old deserted house gave me an eerie feeling.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eeriness

form.definition: noun If something has an effect on another thing, it causes a change in it. All my nagging has no effectshe still won't keep her room tidy. Smoking can have a serious effect on your health.
noun The effect something has is the impression it makes. For a softer effect, avoid natural lighting. I like the effect that old-fashioned writing gives on an invitation.
take effect When something takes effect, it begins to work as it should. The medicine should take effect within ten minutes. The new rules will take effect from next month.

adjective Something that is effective produces the result you want. It works well. Driving at a moderate speed is an effective way of saving fuel. We need someone who will be effective in the sales area.

adjective An effective role or result is the one that actually happens or occurs in practice. It is not the official or expected role or result. Mr Stratton is still the owner of the business but his son is the effective manager. ... WORD FAMILYadverb effectively He works quickly and effectively. His son is effectively the manager.noun effectiveness
adjective If someone says that a man is effeminate, they mean that he behaves in a way that they think is too much like a woman.
adjective If a liquid is effervescent, it is fizzy and full of bubbles, like soda water or champagne.
adjective If someone is effervescent, they are lively and cheerful. Her effervescent personality is beginning to get on my nerves.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun effervescence

form.definition: adjective If someone is efficient, they do things well without wasting time. Let's get Mary to organise the partyshe's very efficient.
adjective If something is efficient, it works well and is practical. This vacuum cleaner may have been cheap but it's certainly not efficient.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun efficiency adverb efficiently

form.definition: noun The effort you put into doing something is the mental or physical energy you use. The dinner took a lot of effort, and she never even thanked me. Juan has made a good effort to improve his grades this term. He lifted the heavy case without effort.

noun If you say that something is an effort, you mean it requires more than the usual amount of energy. With my arthritis, just getting up in the morning is an effort. Giving up smoking was a real effort, I can tell you!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective effortless My aerobics instructor makes it look so easy, so effortless.

form.definition: noun EFTPOS is a way of paying for things using a plastic card and a PIN (personal identification number) which only you know. You key your PIN into a terminal, and money is automatically transferred from your bank account to the shop's account.
form.note: ... NOTEEFTPOS is an acronym made from the words electronic funds transfer at point of sale.

form.definition: abbreviation for the Latin words exempli gratia, which mean 'for example'. We have books in many foreign languages, e.g. Japanese, French, Arabic and Vietnamese.
noun An egg is a round or oval object produced by a female animal. If the egg is fertilised by a male, a baby animal will develop. Some insects lay thousands of eggs at a time.
noun Egg most often refers to a hen's egg, which we eat as food. Bacon and eggs may taste great, but they're not the best for your health.
as sure as eggs If you say that something will happen as sure as eggs, you mean there is no doubt about it happening. Efrem will win this race, as sure as eggs.
egg on If you egg someone on to do something bad, you encourage them to do it. Two louts were having a fight, with their mates egging them on.
egg on your face If you say someone has egg on their face, you mean that they are humiliated because they have done something foolish. If my plan doesn't work I'll have egg on my face.
noun Your ego is the amount of confidence you have in yourself and your own ability. Losing his job was a big blow to his ego. She's certainly got a big ego.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun egotist He's a real egotistonly ever thinks of himself!

form.definition: noun An eiderdown is a warm quilt for a bed, filled with feathers or synthetic fibres. You put it on the bed on top of the sheets.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with doona.

form.definition: noun Eight is the number 8, five plus three. There are eight of us in the class.
adjective If you have eight things, it means the things you have add up to eight. There are eight desks in the room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See eighth.

form.definition: noun Eighteen is the number 18, ten plus eight. I'll have eighteen of those apples, please.
adjective If you have eighteen things, it means the things you have add up to eighteen. Only eighteen people came to the meeting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See eighteenth.

form.definition: adjective The eighteenth person or thing is the one that comes in order after the seventeenth. She's the eighteenth person to come down with the diseasewe just hope that she's the last.
noun An eighteenth is also one of eighteen equal parts.
adjective The eighth person or thing is the one that comes in order after the seventh. That's the eighth person I've seen come through the gate.
noun An eighth is also one of eight equal parts. I cut the cake into eighths.
noun Eighty is the number 80, eight lots of ten.
adjective If you have eighty things, it means the number of things you have adds up to eighty.
eighties The eighties in the twentieth century are the years from 1980 to 1989. In the nineteenth century they are from 1880 to 1889, and so on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective eightieth He's celebrating his eightieth birthday today.

form.definition: determiner If you are talking about two alternatives, you use either to refer to one or the other of them. You can put the book in either bagI'll be taking them both. I've lived in Sydney and Melbourne, but I didn't like either city much.

pronoun You can also use either on its own to refer to one or the other of two alternatives that you have mentioned. Michelle wants to go into sales or public relationseither would suit her very well. I didn't buy either of the cars. 'Do you want the red or the green?' 'EitherI don't mind.'

determiner If you are talking about two similar things, either can also mean both of those things. On either side of the river, tall trees moved in the breeze. The rod is fixed to the wall by nails at either end.

adverb Either can mean 'also' when it is used to connect two negative statements. The students don't know what you're talking about. I don't either. Polly's refused to help, and I suppose Sam won't either.

either...or If you want to refer first to one possible situation and then to another, you use the words either...or, with either before the first situation and or before the second. Either you love the man or you don'tit's time you made up your mind. Get either white or brown breadit doesn't really matter. Was either Nadia or Lorelle there?

verb In fairly formal language, if you eject someone or something, you remove them or send them out by force. The manager summoned security to eject the drunk from the club. You put the coins in this slot, and the can is ejected into the tray below.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ejection

dictionary.entry:
elaborate@`lAb@r@t <for sense 1; for sense 2,>@`lAb@rEIt
adjective If something is elaborate, it is very detailed or complicated. She made elaborate preparations for her daughter's visit. I can't cook anything more elaborate than an omelette. It doesn't need to be anything elaborate, just a short note.
verb If you elaborate on something, you give more details about it so as to explain it more fully. Could you elaborate on your point about increasing sales? The minister declined to elaborate on her earlier statement.
... WORD FAMILYnoun elaboration The food is simple, without elaboration. This issue needs further elaboration.

form.definition: verb In formal language, when you say that time elapses, you mean that it passes by. Ten years had elapsed since she last saw him.

adjective If something is elastic, you can stretch it but it returns to its original size or shape when you let go. Some types of rubber are more elastic than others. I need an elastic bandage for my knee.

noun Elastic is material, usually in a long strip, that you stretch to put around something to keep it together or to keep it tight. My pyjamas need new elastic in the waist to keep them from falling down.
elastic band An elastic band is a circle of thin rubber that stretches when you put it around things to keep them together.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is rubber band.

form.definition: adjective In fairly formal language, if you say you are elated about something, you mean that you are very excited and happy about it. I was exhausted, but elated to have completed the race. She was welcomed at the airport by elated crowds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun elation

form.definition: noun Your elbow is the joint between your upper and lower arm.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: verb If you elbow someone, you push them with your elbow. I was about to tell the whole story, but Ahmed elbowed me to be quiet. She elbowed her way into the crowded room. He elbowed me aside to get on the bus first.
adjective The elder of two people in a family is the one who was born first. My elder brother lives in Thailand. May I introduce my elder daughter, Amy?
noun An elder is an older, experienced person who deserves respect. This word is usually used to describe the older people in tribal communities. The elders pass on the traditional ways of the tribe.
adjective If we say someone is elderly, they are probably older than 65. Zhang has to support seven siblings and his elderly parents.
form.note: ... NOTEthat this word is thought to be more polite than old.

form.definition: adjective The eldest of a group of people is the one who was born first. Michael is my eldest child.
verb If someone is elected to a position or to do something, they win an election. The class elected Hassan to be their representative on the student council.
verb In formal language, if you elect to do something, you choose to do it as an alternative to something else. You may elect to pay the tax as a lump sum or in instalments.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See elective.noun elector The elected representative has a responsibility to the electors.noun See election.adjective electoral All citizens must be registered on the electoral roll.

form.definition: noun An election is a democratic process which allows people to vote for leaders in government, trade unions, clubs and other organisations. Voting can be by secret ballot or by show of hands. The person with the most votes is elected. The next item on the agenda is the election of officers. Federal elections have to be held every three years.

adjective If something is said to be elective, it means that you can choose to do it if you want to. It is not compulsory or necessary. What are your elective subjects this year? There is a long waiting list for elective surgery in this hospital.

noun An elective is a subject that a student can choose to study. It is not a compulsory subject. 'What's your favourite elective, Ruth?' 'Geography.' The school offers a range of electives such as Japanese, Ancient History and Economics.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See elect.

form.definition: noun An electorate is the area or region that a member of parliament represents. The Opposition's candidate has been criticised for not living in the electorate.

noun The electorate of a country or an area is all the people in it who have the right to vote. The Prime Minister appealed to the electorate to return his party to office. These measures have been deeply unpopular with the electorate.
noun If you are an electrician, your job is to install and repair the electrical wiring in buildings. You'll need a licensed electrician to put those lights inyou're not allowed to do it yourself.
noun Electricity is a form of energy which provides power for lights, machines and appliances. The electricity's gone offhave we got a torch?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective electric, electrical ...electric current. ...electrical engineering.

form.definition: verb If someone is electrocuted, they are killed by an electric shock. He didn't know what he was doing and was electrocuted when he tried to fix the faulty light switch.

adjective Electronic equipment operates by means of an electric current passing through valves, transistors or other similar devices called semiconductors. The water level is controlled by an electronic device. I'm studying electronic engineering.
adjective You say someone is elegant if they are well dressed and graceful. She's a tall, elegant woman who often wears black. You look extremely elegant in that jacket.
adjective Something is elegant if it is stylish and tasteful. There was an elegant flower arrangement in the centre of the table.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun elegance Enjoy the elegance and luxury of our five-star hotel.

form.definition: noun An element of something is one part or aspect of it. It is combined with other elements to make up the whole. That's only one element of the story. What are the others? The work of a lifesaver has several elementssurf rescue and first aid are just two of them.
noun An element is the part of an electrical appliance such as a toaster or kettle that heats up when the electricity is turned on.
noun In chemistry, an element is a substance that can't be broken down into anything else.

adjective If something is elementary, it is very easy or simple. I signed up for a course in elementary mechanics. This textbook is too elementary for youyou need something more advanced. After I'd sorted that out, the rest was elementary.

verb In formal language, if you elevate someone or something, you raise them to a higher position. He was later elevated to the position of Cardinal. The injured limb is elevated in order to promote healing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun elevation The elevation here is 300 metres above sea level.

form.definition: noun Elevator is another word for lift.
noun Eleven is the number 11, ten plus one. With eleven on the bushwalk, we'll need at least four tents.
adjective If you have eleven things, it means the number of things you have adds up to eleven. I've got eleven eggs left out of that dozen that I bought.
noun An eleven is a team of people in cricket. Navin's in the first eleven for his school.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See eleventh.

form.definition: adjective The eleventh person or thing is the one that comes in order after the tenth. He was the eleventh person to die. 2 noun An eleventh is also one of eleven equal parts.

adjective If you are eligible for something or to do something, you meet the requirements that are needed for it. After two years as a permanent resident you are eligible for Australian citizenship. Only financial members are eligible to vote.
verb If you eliminate something, you get rid of it or remove it. This poison will eliminate weeds from your garden. We were eliminated in the fifth round of the tournament.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun elimination

form.definition: noun The elite in a society are the group with the most money, power or authority. The wedding was attended by many of Melbourne's elite. University education should not be confined to an intellectual elite.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective elite She rejected her elite upbringing. Enjoy the luxury of our elite resort.

form.definition: noun An ellipse is a shape in geometry that we otherwise call oval.

adjective If you are eloquent you speak well and are able to express your ideas very clearly and persuasively. The guest speaker was eloquent and amusing. He has always been an eloquent opponent of discrimination. Tony seemed shy, but on the topic of surfing he became eloquent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eloquence

form.definition: adverb Else can mean 'more' or 'in addition'. What else can I tell you? Who else is coming? We still need something else to serve with the meat.

adverb You can also use else to mean 'other than that' or 'instead'. I don't like chickenisn't there anything else? Jane's away, so we'll have to ask someone else. Of course they're minewho else's could they be?
or else You can use or else in order to emphasise an alternative possibility. I think I'll have the fish, or else maybe the chicken. You must stop drinking, or else you'll end up in hospital.

adverb Elsewhere means 'at another place' or 'to another place'. This is the third mistake your company has made with our order. If this happens again, we will be forced to go elsewhere for our supplies.

adjective If something is elusive, it is hard to find or obtain. A formal proof for the theorem has proved elusive. Tom's pretty elusive, but you might catch him at home. We offer a book search service to track down elusive publications.
noun If you use e-mail to send a message to someone, you use a computer to send it. E-mail is short for 'electronic mail'.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is email. ... WORD FAMILYverb email He emailed a reply to his colleague.

form.definition: noun An embargo is an official ban that limits or prevents trade, the movement of ships, or other activities. The United Nations has imposed a world trade embargo on the regime. She proposes lifting the embargo on the export of native animals.
verb If you embark on a ship, you go on board before the start of a cruise or voyage. Passengers may embark up to three hours before departure.

embark on If you embark on an activity, you begin it. The guests will be here in an hour, and I haven't even embarked on cooking dinner. There isn't time to embark on a discussion of that now. We wish you well as you embark on your new life.
verb If you embarrass someone, you make them feel awkward, slightly ashamed, or self-conscious. I embarrassed my son by kissing him in front of his friends.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun embarrassment I flushed red with embarrassment. His work is an embarrassment to the company.

form.definition: noun An embassy is the official headquarters used by a foreign ambassador and diplomatic staff. Australia has an embassy in most of the capital cities of the world.
verb If someone embezzles, they steal money secretly from the place where they work. Over two years Michael embezzled $20 000 from the bank where he was employed as an accountant.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun embezzlement

form.definition: noun An emblem is an object which represents something or is the sign of something. The floral emblem of New South Wales is the waratah. ...a badge with the school emblem on it.
verb If you embrace someone, you take them in your arms and hug them. You do this to show love or affection. The two sisters embraced when they were re-united at the airport.
noun Embrace is a fairly formal word for a hug. The brothers were locked in a tender embrace.

verb In formal language, if you say that someone embraces something such as an idea or a religion, you mean that they start to believe in it or accept it. He embraced the Catholic religion late in life. Some of their marital problems are due to their refusal to embrace change.
verb If you embroider a piece of cloth, you decorate it with fancy needle-work. I embroidered the tablecloth with a floral design.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun embroidery (embroideries) She teaches embroidery. ...an exhibition of medieval embroideries.

form.definition: noun An embryo is a baby animal in the early stages of development. It is inside the egg, or in the mother's body.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective embryonic

form.definition: noun An emerald is a precious stone which is bright green in colour. ...a ring set with emeralds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective emerald Her dress was an emerald colour.

form.definition: verb If you emerge from somewhere, you appear or come into view. When the plane emerged from the clouds, Adelaide lay below us. Often he takes to his study and doesn't emerge for hours.

verb In slightly formal language, if a fact emerges, it becomes known or the public finds out about it. It eventually emerged that she had arranged the whole thing. An alarming tale of police corruption is emerging.
noun An emergency is a sudden, unexpected happening, when help is needed straight away. In case of emergency, dial 000 for fire, police or ambulance. If there's an emergency, call me on this number.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective emergency ...emergency exit. ...the emergency services. Carry some emergency cash.

form.definition: noun An emigrant is someone who leaves their own country to live in another country. The emigrants had one last look at their homeland as the plane took off.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis word with immigrant. ... WORD FAMILYnoun emigration

form.definition: verb If you emigrate, you leave your own country to go and live in another country. They're thinking of emigrating because life is so hard.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis word with immigrate. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See emigrant.

form.definition: adjective If someone is eminent, they are well-known and respected, usually because they are very good at their job. The committee contained a number of eminent scientists.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eminence

form.definition: noun Your emotions are your feelings. Her voice was distorted by emotion. I felt a mixture of emotionsshock, anger and grief.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective emotional Try not to get emotional about it. He's a very emotional person.

form.definition: noun If you put emphasis on something, you believe that it is very important. In this school a lot of emphasis is put on the arts. The report places a heavy emphasis on the need for reform. In his novels there is an emphasis on the dark side of life.

noun Emphasis is also the stress that you place on a particular part of a word, or on a particular word in a sentence. In the name 'Suzanne', the emphasis is on the second syllable. The meaning of the question varies according to where you put the emphasis. She's very mean, with the emphasis on 'very'.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb emphasise (<or> emphasize) The doctor emphasised the importance of diet. Which syllable is emphasised?adjective emphatic The answer is an emphatic 'no'. He was most emphatic about that point.

form.definition: noun An empire is a group of countries or peoples that are governed by one ruler. Many of the former colonies of the British Empire now belong to the Commonwealth of Nations.
noun You can also use empire to mean a group of businesses or organisations under the control of one person or family. The family's newspaper empire was gradually sold off.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun emperor ...the emperor Nero.noun empress Catherine the Great was empress of Russia from 1725-27.

form.definition: verb If you employ someone, you hire them as a paid worker. We need to employ extra staff to cope with the rush. The company employs over two hundred people.
verb In formal language, if you employ something, you use it. They employ the latest technology. We have been forced to employ severe cost control measures.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun employee All company employees will get a pay rise tomorrow.noun employer The company has a good reputation as an employer.noun employment How long have you been seeking employment?

form.definition: adjective If something is empty, it doesn't contain anything. There is nothing in it. Do you want to keep those empty boxes? The room was completely empty of furniture. This bottle's nearly empty.
adjective You can also say that a place like a room or a house is empty if there are no people there. I don't like coming home at night to an empty house. My footsteps echoed in the empty darkness.

adjective If you say that words are empty, you mean that the person who spoke or wrote them does not really mean what they say. I'm sick of your empty promisesyou never keep your word. That's an empty threathe's just bluffing.
verb If you empty something, you take out what was inside. You remove the contents. We'll have to empty the drawers before we move the cupboard. He emptied the box into the rubbish bin.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun emptiness After the crowd left, a sense of emptiness filled the grandstand.

form.definition: noun An emu is a large Australian bird with very long legs. It can't fly but it can run very fast. The emu and the kangaroo are the animals on the Australian coat of arms.

verb If something enables you to do something, it makes it possible for you to do it. This is a fairly formal word. The scholarship will enable the holder to spend six months studying in Europe. The stepladder enables me to reach the top shelves.
noun Enamel is a hard, glossy coating which can be put onto metal or pottery, to protect it or as a decoration. The enamel's chipping off this saucepan.
noun Enamel is also hard-wearing, shiny, oil-based paint. We painted all the woodwork with enamel, and the walls with acrylic.
noun The outer protective layer on your teeth is also called enamel.

verb If you enclose something, you surround it with something or shut it in on all sides. We decided to enclose the back veranda last year, and now it's a large rumpus room. The object of the game is to enclose your opponent so that they are unable to move.
verb If you enclose something with a letter or with goods, you post it in the same envelope or package. Don't forget to enclose a cheque with your order.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun enclosure The enclosures seem to be missing from the envelope.

form.definition: verb If you encode a message, you put it into code.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is decode.

form.definition: noun An encore is an extra song or item performed at the end of a performance because the audience wants to hear more.
verb If you encounter a problem or difficulty, you are faced with it unexpectedly. Call me back if you encounter any further difficulties with the machine.
noun If you have an encounter with someone or something, you have to deal with a difficult situation that they cause. The encounter with my ex-wife wasn't pleasant, I can tell you.

verb If you encourage someone, you support them in what they want to do. John's got an important match tonight, so I'm going along to encourage him. I'd like to thank my parents, who encouraged me through all the years of training.
verb If you encourage something, you support it and try to help it become bigger or better. We try to encourage the talents of all our pupils.
verb If you encourage someone to do something, you suggest that they should do it. My doctor encouraged me to give up smoking. We encourage all our students to study a language.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun encouragement I couldn't have done it without your encouragement.adjective encouraging He sent me a kind, encouraging letter. The response has been most encouraging.

form.definition: noun An encyclopedia is a book or set of books that contains information on many different subjects. The articles are usually in alphabetical order.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is encyclopaedia.

form.definition: noun The end of something is the last part of it, or the finishing point. I want to get to the end of this book tonight. That fight was the end of their relationship. The cafe is right at the end of the street. Which end of the table did he sit at?

verb If something ends, it stops or finishes. The film ends at 6.40. The tar road ends at the bottom of the hill. It's hard to say where one thing ends and the other begins. The letter ended with greetings to my family.

verb If you end something, you finish it or bring it to a close. In order to end the rumours about my intentions, I'm announcing my resignation today. You should end your essay with a summary of your conclusions.

end up If you end up in a place or situation, you find yourself there, often without planning it. If you're not careful, you'll end up in hospital. I didn't do enough work and ended up failing my exams. She's a bright girlshe'll end up really making something of her life.

make ends meet If you make ends meet, you earn enough to pay for your needs. You are able to manage on your income. I don't earn a fortune, but I make ends meet. It's very hard to make ends meet on a pension.

the end If you say that someone or something is the end, you mean that you are very impatient and annoyed with them. That's the third time he's been latehe really is the end. This computer's the absolute endit's really driving me mad.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ending ...a happy ending.adjective endless I'm fed up with this endless rain.

form.definition: verb If you endanger someone or something, you put them in a dangerous situation. Your carelessness has endangered us all.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective endangered The platypus is an endangered species.

form.definition: verb If you endeavour to do something, you try very hard to do it. I will endeavour to do the best I can to find a place for you.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is endeavor. ... WORD FAMILYnoun endeavour Good luck in your new business endeavour.

form.definition: verb If you endorse a document, you write something on it or sign your name on it. This cheque should be endorsed 'not negotiable'. She forgot to endorse her cheque and the teller refused to cash it.

verb If you endorse someone or something, you show your approval by some public action. The strike has been endorsed by the Labor Council. The minister agreed to endorse their campaign. Sporting personalities earn millions from endorsing products.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun endorsement The policy has not yet received official endorsement.

form.definition: verb If you endure something difficult or painful, you suffer it or put up with it. Ling endured some terrible experiences in her homeland. I can't endure the pain a moment longer! We had to endure another tedious evening in his company.
verb In formal language, if something endures, it lasts for a long time. The family feud endured for several generations. She believed their love would endure forever.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun endurance The marathon is a big test of endurance.adjective enduring ...the search for an enduring peace.

form.definition: noun Your enemy is someone who hates you and wants to do you harm. The police asked whether the murdered man had any enemies. The two families have been bitter enemies for generations.
noun The enemy during a war is an opposing army or group. They received orders to advance on the enemy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective enemy ...enemy troops.

form.definition: noun Your energy is the amount of strength and vitality you have. The children have so much energythey wear me out! I just haven't got the energy to go out tonight. Carbohydrates give you energy. I put all my mental energies into the task.
noun Energy is also the power from something like electricity, gas or coal. This electric heater uses a lot of energy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective energetic I don't feel very energetic today. ...energetic exercise.adjective energy ...the energy crisis.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you engage someone, you employ or hire them to do a job. We are seeking to engage an accountant, with at least five years' experience. She was engaged as a consultant to review their production processes.

engaged (a) If a telephone is engaged, you can't speak to the person you have rung because their telephone is being used for another call. The line is busy. I tried to call you earlier, but you were engaged. ...the engaged tone.
(b) In rather formal language, if you are engaged in something, you do it or are involved with it. I'm presently engaged in research work for a drug company.

(c) If two people get engaged, they decide (and usually tell everyone) that they are going to marry each other. Khaled and Rita got engaged last Saturday. Didn't you know they're engaged? She's engaged to a farmer.
noun An engagement is an agreement between two people that they will marry each other. Howard and Rosie announced their engagement last night; they're get- ting married next month.

noun An engagement is also an appointment or an arrangement that you have made to go somewhere, meet someone or do something at a particular time. I can't make it on Friday; I have another engagement. He had to cancel several concert engagements because of poor health.
noun An engine is a machine which uses energy, such as from petrol, coal or electricity, to make something move. There's something wrong with the engine in my car.
noun The locomotive which pulls train carriages is also called an engine.

noun An engineer is someone who is trained to use scientific and mathematical principles to design and build constructions and machinery. ...a civil engineer. ...an electrical engineer. ...a chemical engineer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun engineering ...mechanical engineering. ...genetic engineering. ...social engineering.

form.definition: noun English is the official language spoken in countries such as the UK, Australia, the USA and Canada.
adjective If someone or something is English, they come from England. My mother's English but my father's Australian.

verb If you engrave something such as stone or metal, you cut into it with a sharp tool, to leave words or a design on the surface. I've had the back of my watch engraved with my name and phone number.
verb If something is engraved in your memory, you remember it very clearly. You never forget it. The awful scene is engraved in my mind to this day. Her last words remained engraved in his heart.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun engraving ...a wood engraving.

form.definition: verb If you enjoy something, you get pleasure from it. Did you enjoy the film last night? He doesn't seem to be enjoying his meal. I enjoy walks and seeing new places. I don't enjoy having to wait for a bus in the rain.

verb If you enjoy something good or desirable, you have it. I'm lucky enough to enjoy good health. Most Australians enjoy a relatively high standard of living. The nation enjoyed a long period of prosperity.
enjoy yourself If you enjoy yourself, you have fun. Everyone seems to be enjoying themselvesthe party's a great success!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective enjoyable Thank youI've had a most enjoyable evening.noun enjoyment I get a lot of enjoyment from gardening.

form.definition: verb If you enlarge something, you make it bigger. I had some of the best photos enlarged. The committee decided to enlarge the scope of their investigation. Use a knife to enlarge the hole.
verb If something enlarges, it gets bigger. The town has enlarged greatly over the last ten years. The area of damage is enlarging all the time.
enlarge on If you enlarge on something, you give more details about it. Could you enlarge a little on your plans? I'd like to enlarge on what Sten has just said.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun enlargement This photo of Joe is goodI'll get an enlargement.

form.definition: verb If you enlist in the army, navy or air force, you join by your own choice. Mark was determined to enlist as soon as he was old enough.
verb If you enlist someone or someone's service, you get them to help you do something. I enlisted the help of my cousin to build the wall.

adjective If something is enormous, it is very large or great. They live in an enormous house. Your singing gave me enormous pleasure. He earns an enormous amount of money. The earthquake did enormous damage. ... WORD FAMILYadverb enormously

determiner If something is enough, it is sufficient, and you don't need more of it. Sometimes you have enough and you don't want any moremore would be too much. Have you got enough money for the bus fare? There wasn't enough information to solve the problem. I've got enough problems at the moment without the car breaking down.

pronoun If you have enough of something, you have as much as you need. You don't need or want any more. I earn just about enough to live on. They eat enough to feed an army. I've heard quite enough about him and his problems. I've got enough to do without clearing up after you.

adverb If something is good enough or strong enough, it is as good or strong as it needs to be. It doesn't need to be any more so, or it shouldn't be any more so. I live near enough to the office to walk to work. You've worked enough for one day. Things were bad enough before this.

fair enough If you say that something is fair enough, you mean that it is reasonable and you are quite happy with it. If you can't come, that's fair enoughI know you're very busy. $20 would be fair enough, but $30 is far too much.

that's enough If you say to someone that's enough, you mean that you want them to stop what they are doing, because it is annoying you. That's enough! Stop fighting right nowor you'll both have to go to your rooms!
noun In fairly formal language, if you make an enquiry, you ask a question or request some information. We've had lots of enquiries in response to our advertisement.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis word to inquiry. An enquiry is usually a simple question while an inquiry is often an official investigation. ... WORD FAMILYverb enquire I'd like to enquire about the cleaning job advertised in the paper.

form.definition: verb If something enrages you, it makes you very angry. His insolence enraged her. I was enraged by the delay.
verb If you enrich something, you make it better by adding something to it. This cereal is enriched with vitamins and minerals. Art enriches our lives. ... WORD FAMILYnoun enrichment

verb If you enrol at a college or in a class, you put your name on an official list to become a member of it. I'd like to enrol in the course in psychology. All students must enrol at least two weeks before the beginning of term. Have you enrolled your children at school yet?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun enrolment

form.definition: noun An ensuite is a small extra bathroom attached to a bedroom, often the main bedroom.

verb In fairly formal language, if you ensure that something happens, you make sure that it happens. You take responsibility for it. I left early to ensure that I'd arrive on time. Please ensure that you have enclosed the necessary documents.
adjective If something is entangled in something else, it is caught in it and can't get free. My feet were entangled in the rope. Several prominent politicians were entangled in the scandal.

verb In rather formal language, if you enter something, you come or go into it. He entered the room cautiously. Please knock before entering. On what date did you first enter Australia? Passengers should enter the bus by the front doors. 2a verb If you enter something such as a competition, a race or a discussion, you get involved in it. You join in the activity. She entered politics at the age of thirty. His marks were not good enough to enter university. I was reluctant to enter the controversy.

verb If you enter someone or something in a competition or race, you arrange for them to take part. We've decided to enter Narelle in both events. I've entered three of my paintings in the art competition.
verb If you enter something on a list, in a book, and so on, you write it down. She entered my name on the list for the barbecue. We need someone to enter the results in the database.

enter into If you enter into something, you become involved in it as the result of your own decision. She entered into the contract knowing all the facts. I'm reluctant to enter into a binding commitment. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See entrance.noun See entrant.noun See entry.
noun An enterprise is a commercial company or business. They're one of the largest retail enterprises in Australia.

noun In rather formal language, an enterprise is a task that requires quite a lot of time and effort. Studying for a degree is not an enterprise to be undertaken without careful thought and planning. Now I wish I'd never started on the whole enterprise.

noun Enterprise is also the imagination, courage and determination that you use to deal with difficult situations. She showed considerable enterprise in finding a job through her own efforts. You have to use a bit of enterprise and not expect everything to be organised for you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective enterprising He's a very enterprising young man.

form.definition: noun Enterprise bargaining is the negotiation of wages and working conditions between the management of a particular company or organisation and the workers there. The arrangements apply to that company only.

verb If you entertain someone, you do something that they find enjoyable or interesting. She entertained us all with her funny stories. The dancers entertained a large crowd. A few simple toys can entertain a toddler for hours.

verb If you entertain guests, you serve them food and drink and talk to them. You'd better go and entertain Alex and Rob while I finish cooking the meal. He's a great cook, and he really enjoys entertaining.
verb In formal language, if you entertain an idea, you are prepared to consider it. She refused to entertain the possibility of failure. How can you entertain the notion of marrying him?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun entertainer She's studying singing, and would like to be a professional entertainer.adjective entertaining The performance was very entertaining. He told some entertaining stories.noun entertainment The admission price covers food, drink and entertainment.

form.definition: noun Enthusiasm is great interest and excitement about something. Their enthusiasm is clearthey can't wait to start! The proposal met with general enthusiasm. You might show a bit more enthusiasm! He plays with more enthusiasm than skill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective enthusiastic I'm not very enthusiastic about the idea. She's an enthusiastic swimmer.

form.definition: verb If you entice someone to do something, you get them to do it by making it seem very attractive. She was enticed back to her old job by the promise of much higher pay. She claimed that advertisements were enticing children to demand expensive toys.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective enticing ...an enticing prospect.

form.definition: adjective You use entire to emphasise that you mean the whole of something, not just part of it. Sara ate the entire cake by herself. I've never seen such a big one in my entire life. The entire school lined up to greet the visitor. We'll have to repaint the entire room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb entirely She was dressed entirely in green. I agree with you entirely.

form.definition: verb If something entitles you to something, it gives you the right to have it or do it. This pass entitles you to free entry. Only citizens over the age of 18 are entitled to vote. Surely all my hard work entitles me to a share of the credit?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun entitlement

dictionary.entry:
entrance`Entr@ns <for the noun; for the verb,>En`trAns
noun An entrance is the place where you go into a building or enclosed area. The entrance to the theatre was blocked by the crowd. I'll meet you at the entrance at seven o'clock. The yacht sank right by the harbour entrance.
noun If you make an entrance, you go into a room or other area where there is an audience. The band made their entrance on stage to the cheers of the crowd. She was deliberately late in order to make a dramatic entrance.
noun In formal language, entrance also means the act of going into a building or enclosed area. NO ENTRANCE The guards refused us entrance to the meeting.
verb If you entrance someone, you delight and charm them. Maria was entranced by the antics of the young acrobats.

form.definition: noun An entrant is someone who takes part in a competition or race. All entrants will receive a special medal. Entrants for the 5000 metres should now proceed to the starting line.
verb In formal language, if you entreat someone to do something, you beg them to do it. He entreated her to keep his secret. Don't leave me, I entreat you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun entreaty (entreaties) He refused to yield to her entreaties.

form.definition: noun An entree is a dish of food that you eat before the main course at dinner. We had fresh oysters as an entree and grilled fish as the main course.
noun An entrepreneur is someone who organises and invests in an activity, project or business. Their aim is to make a large profit, even though there are risks involved.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective entrepreneurial She showed great entrepreneurial flair.

form.definition: noun Your entry into a place is your arrival or going in. Initial entry to Australia must be made within a year of the grant of the residence visa. Entry to the restaurant is via the lane. NO ENTRY
noun An entry is a written record, or an item in a list. There's an entry on my bank statement I don't understandsee this withdrawal of $100? ...a dictionary entry.
noun Your entry in a competition is what you submit to be chosen or judged. All entries must be received by 30 September. Julia Chan's winning entry is illustrated below.
noun An envelope is a paper cover for a letter. She ripped open the envelope eagerly.
noun The environment is made up of all the natural things in the world around us, such as the sea, land, animals and plants. We want to educate people to protect the environment.
noun Your environment consists of all the things that influence you or play a part in your life. A happy environment is helpful to a child's development.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective environmental ...environmental protection.

dictionary.entry:
envy`Envi:enviesenviedenvying 1a verb If you envy someone, you wish that you had the same things as they have. I can't help envying Paulhe's so clever. Jenny had always
noun Envy is the feeling you get when you would like to have the same things that someone else has. Gina's talent fills me with envy.
the envy of If something or someone is the envy of other people, those people wish they had that thing, or were like that person. Her beautiful garden is the envy of all her friends. When Sean went out with Zina, he was the envy of all his mates.
... WORD FAMILYadjective envious It's hard not to be envious of his good fortune.adverb enviously She looked enviously at my plate of oysters.

form.definition: noun An epic is a long narration about heroic achievements or adventures. In informal language, the word is often used humorously about everyday things. I love the old epics from Hollywood, even though they lasted for hours. It sounds as if your trip to Europe was quite an epic!

adjective Something epic is grand and heroic, involving brave deeds. In informal language, the word is often used humorously about everyday things. They never returned from their epic exploration of central Australia. She told me all about her epic search for a corkscrew.
noun An epidemic occurs when many people catch the same illness at the same time. Her parents died in the influenza epidemic of 1919.
noun Epilepsy is a brain disorder which produces fits. During the fits, the person may lose consciousness for a short time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective epileptic

form.definition: noun An episode is an event or a particular period of time. My year overseas was one of the happiest episodes of my life. I just want to put the whole episode behind me.
noun An episode is one program in a television or radio serial. Did you see last night's episode? They screened a special anniversary program to mark the 100th episode.

noun In formal language, if you say that something is the epitome of a certain quality, you mean that it is a very good example of it. Their house is the epitome of gracious livingverandas on all sides and large rooms with fireplaces and high ceilings. He's the epitome of the absent-minded professor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb epitomise (<or> epitomize) The region epitomises rural tranquility.

form.definition: noun In formal language, an epoch is a long period of time in which many important events happen. She lived through an eventful epoch of history.

adjective If two or more things are equal, they are the same in some measurement such as amount, size or weight. She cut two equal pieces of cake. The women claimed equal pay for work of equal value. We should have equal rights with the permanent staff.
form.note: ... COMPARE THISto equivalent.b adjective Something is equal if the different elements in it are the same in some measurement such as amount or strength. Make an equal mixture of sand and cement. In boxing, weight divisions make the fights more equal. If you confront the boss, be aware it won't be an equal contest.

form.definition: verb If something equals something else, it is exactly the same. It is equivalent to it. Twelve divided by four equals three. In Australian cookery books, four teaspoons equal one tablespoon. Her refusal to meet us equals a deliberate snub.

verb If you equal something, you match it. You do the same thing as someone else, or you do as well as they did. His time equalled the world 1500 metres record. They've been offered $650 000 for the house. How can we equal that? She had always wanted to equal her sister in her achievement.

noun In rather formal language, if you say someone is the equal of someone else, you mean they are the same in some quality. They are just as strong or clever or brave, for example. She's very intelligent, but he's her equal. He didn't regard any of us as his intellectual equals.

adverb If something is equal first or equal best with something else, then both of them are first or best. They are the same as each other, so you can't say which of them is the first or best overall. She came equal first in the state in the school-leaving examination. Jane and Cheryl shared equal fourth place.

equal to (a) If something is equal to something else, it is exactly the same. The figure you get should be equal to half the one above. What she spends on clothes is equal to what we pay for food and rent. I take it your silence is equal to consent.

(b) If you are equal to someone or something, you are clever or strong enough to be able to deal with them. He's a tough manager, but Sue's equal to him. I really don't feel equal to a long walk today. We need to find staff who'll be equal to the challenge of competition.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb equalise (<or> equalize) We must equalise results between the sexes. Theo equalised the score.noun equality Women have had to struggle to achieve some measure of social equality.adverb equally I love all my children equally. The next day was equally hot.

form.definition: noun The equator is an imaginary line around the earth. It is halfway between the North Pole and the South Pole. Countries on the equator have very hot climates.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective equatorial

form.definition: verb If you equip someone or something, you supply them with whatever they need for a particular task or situation. Please equip your child with a packed lunch, sun cream and a hat for the excursion. This bicycle comes fully equipped with pump, repair kit and rear-vision mirror.

verb If you equip someone to do something, you teach or train them. You develop their skills and abilities. The course equips students to succeed in the commercial world. My nursing experience equipped me to cope calmly. He should be well equipped to deal with the problem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See equipment.

form.definition: noun Equipment is anything you need for a particular task or situation. It could be things like tools, machines or special clothes. Have you loaded all the camping equipment? He spent a fortune on the best camera equipment. They make laboratory equipment.

adjective If two or more things are equivalent, they are equal in value or other qualities, although they are different in other ways. Equivalent jobs in the private sector carry much higher salaries.
noun If something is the equivalent of something else, it has the same role in a different system. The Victorian Certificate of Education is the equivalent of the NSW Higher School Certificate.

equivalent to If something is equivalent to something else, it is the same as it in effect, although it may seem to be different in some respects. Two thirds times three quarters is equivalent to one half. His resignation was equivalent to a rejection of the entire system.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun equivalence

form.definition: noun An era is a period of time which is remembered because of a particular event, person or style. The 1960s was the era of the mini-skirt. In the modern era, computers have taken over many of the tasks that used to be done by workers.

verb In rather formal language, if you eradicate something, you get rid of it completely or destroy it. We must take strong measures to eradicate environmental pollution. They called in a company to eradicate rats from the property.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eradication

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you erase something, you rub it out, or remove any sign or trace of it. Some numbers have obviously been erased from the cheque. I can't erase those unhappy memories from my mind.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eraser There's an eraser on the end of the pencil.

form.definition: adjective If something is erect, it is upright. It is standing up, or held up straight. The dog waited eagerly, its ears erect and its tail wagging.
adjective If a penis is erect, it is swollen and stiff, usually as a result of sexual excitement.
verb In rather formal language, to erect a building means to construct it. Developers are keen to erect a new shopping centre on the site. They voted to erect a memorial to the firefighters who died.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun erection

form.definition: verb If something erodes or is eroded, it gradually wears away. You should plant trees on the side of the hill to stop the soil eroding. The sea erodes the cliff face by several centimetres a year. ... WORD FAMILYnoun erosion Soil erosion is a problem for farmers who have removed too many trees.
adjective If something is erotic, it has to do with sexual love and sexual desire. The film is regarded as an erotic masterpiece. Some of the dancing was very erotic.
verb In formal language, if you say someone errs, you mean they are mistaken. I'm afraid I erred in saying the meeting would be over by lunch time.

err on the side of caution If you err on the side of caution, you make a decision with the intention that if you are wrong the result will not be too bad. Let's err on the side of caution and catch the early bus.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See error.

form.definition: noun An errand is a small task that involves going out, such as posting a letter or buying something. I've got to go into town on a few errands this morning.

adjective If something is erratic, it is likely to change without warning. You can't rely on it to stay the same. Paul's moods are erraticmostly he's perfectly pleasant, but every so often he flares up. The weather has been very erratic lately. She's a rather erratic student.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb erratically

form.definition: noun An error is a mistake. This is a rather formal word. Delivery was delayed because of an error at the warehouse. Ten points are given for each correct answer, but five are deducted for each error.
verb If a volcano erupts, it sends out molten rocks and ashes into the atmosphere.
verb If you say that someone erupts, you mean that they suddenly show that they are very angry. When I asked how his work was going, he erupted.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eruption[xp\start\escalate

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say something escalates, you mean that it becomes greater or more serious and dangerous. We all fear that the conflict may escalate into a major war. Prices are set to escalate as the shortages get worse.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun escalation

form.definition: noun An escalator is a moving staircase between different levels, usually found in public buildings such as airports and department stores.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with elevator.

form.definition: noun An escapade is a dangerous or foolish adventure, especially if it causes trouble. The girls' latest escapade was to go off to the beach without telling anyone.
verb If you escape, you manage to get away from somewhere. You become free. Several prisoners escaped by hiding from the guards.
verb If you escape something, you avoid it. You manage to miss it. After dinner, the kids always try to escape doing the washing up. I narrowly escaped a collision with a truck.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun escape They planned their escape from gaol. What a narrow escape! I almost died!noun escapee Four of the five escapees were recaptured within hours.

dictionary.entry:
escort@s`k@:t <for the verb; for the noun,> /\times,0\eskt/
verb If you escort someone, you go somewhere with them, usually in order to be polite or to protect them. Allow me to escort you to the lift.
noun An escort is a person or vehicle that goes somewhere with someone, usually as a mark of honour or in order to protect them. The Prime Minister set off for the airport with a police escort.
esky`Eski: (<plural form> eskies) An esky is a special box that you use to keep food and drink cold when you are outside.

form.definition: abbreviation for English as a Second Language.

adverb If you say you like something, believe something or hope something especially, you mean that you like, believe or hope it very much or to a special degree. 'Do you enjoy cooking?' 'Not especially.' ...an especially important date.
adverb If you say that among a group of things you especially like one, you mean that you like that one better than all the others. My daughter loves cakes, especially lamingtons.
noun Espionage is spying. It is finding out secret information about other people, companies or governments. The information is then given or sold to a rival or enemy. ...industrial espionage.
noun An essay is a written composition on a particular subject. I have to write an essay on Australia's role in the United Nations for my politics course.
noun The essence of something is its basic nature or its central or most important aspect. The essence of the problem is that Veronique doesn't like her new boss.
noun The essence of a natural substance is a concentrated form of it. ...vanilla essence. ...essence of roses.

adjective If something is essential, it is absolutely necessary. You cannot manage without it. It is essential that you complete the course of treatment. COURIER WANTED: OWN CAR ESSENTIAL I hope I haven't forgotten anything essential
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun essential I just bought a few essentialsmilk, bread and eggs.

form.definition: verb If you establish something, you set it up and arrange for it to begin operating. We've established a special unit to answer enquiries. The business has been established since 1955.

verb If you establish a fact, you find out about it or prove it to be true. The cause of death has not yet been established. It has now been established that the two men met in 1893. We still need to establish what the costs will be.
verb If you establish yourself in a position, you manage to become settled and accepted in that position. In just under five years she had established herself as a leading solicitor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See establishment.adjective established I'm beginning to feel more established in Australia now.

form.definition: noun The establishment is the main institutions of a society, such as the government, the legal system and the press. The establishment generally represents the traditional way of doing things and is resistant to new ideas and radical change. He used to get very angry about the influence of the establishment.
noun An estate is a large area of land. ...a housing estate. ...an industrial estate.
noun A person's estate is all their possessions that they leave behind when they die. There's a dispute over the distribution of her $200 000 estate.

noun An estate agent is a person who arranges the sale of houses and units. Many estate agents also deal with property for rent and with the sale of plots for building and commercial premises such asshops.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun estate agency (estate agencies) She runs a successful estate agency.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say that you esteem someone, you mean that you think very highly of them. You admire them greatly. I've always esteemed her as a boss.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun esteem I hold him in the highest esteem.

dictionary.entry:
estimate`Est@mEIt <for the verb; for the noun,>
verb If you estimate something, you make a rough calculation. I didn't have a tape measure, so I had to estimate the length. I'd estimate that the cost will be about $300, allowing $10 each. How long do you estimate the journey will take?
noun An estimate is a guess based on some facts. It must be about three kilometres, at a rough estimate. My best estimate of the cost would be between $10 000 and $15 000. Estimates of the total number varied between 200 and 300. b noun If someone such as a plumber or a painter gives you an estimate, they tell you roughly how much they will charge for a job. An estimate is not binding like a quotation, but it should be fairly accurate. I asked for an estimate for having a gas heater fitted.
... WORD FAMILYnoun estimation

form.definition: If you are estranged from your husband or wife, you do not live with him or her any more. <Tom's estranged from his wife. ...her estranged husband>.
If you are estranged from a friend or relative, you do not see them or speak to them because you are not friendly with them any more.

abbreviation for the Latin words et cetera, which mean 'and the rest'. It is used at the end of a list of things to show that other similar things are also meant. Be sure to bring all the pens, pencils, erasers etc. that you'll need. She said that she was sorry I was leaving, that they'd all miss me etc., etc.

verb If you etch something onto a material such as metal or glass, you cut into it with acid to leave a clear, lasting mark. They were given a crystal vase with their initials etched on it. I bought a silver tray etched with a floral design.

verb If you say that something is etched in your memory, you mean that you remember it clearly, usually because it is very distressing. The faces of the starving refugees remain etched in my mind, even after all these years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See etching.

form.definition: noun An etching is a picture printed from a plate that has been etched with a design.
adjective Something is eternal if it lasts forever. Is the universe eternal? The Antarctic is a land of eternal ice.

adjective You can also call something eternal if it goes on all the time or for a long time and you are tired of it. I can't stand the kids' eternal fighting. I wish I could get rid of this eternal cold.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eternity The probe was lost in space for all eternity. I waited for an eternity.

form.definition: noun Ethics are the moral standards and principles that a society accepts as basic rules for behaviour. It's against business ethics to acquire confidential information by deceit.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ethical What she did was not entirely ethical.

form.definition: adjective Ethnic refers to the different races or tribes that people belong to. There are several different ethnic groups in Malaysia. The region has been the scene of much ethnic tension. She's an ethnic Chinese from Vietnam.
adjective Ethnic also refers to cultures in Australia that don't come from the British Isles. Do you like ethnic food? To promote equal opportunities, we must also advertise in the ethnic press.

noun People in Australia who belong to cultures that don't come from the British Isles are sometimes called ethnics. This is an offensive name for them. The representation of women and ethnics in business has traditionally been low.
