noun Etiquette is a standard of formal, polite behaviour that is generally accepted in a particular society. Western etiquette requires you to close your mouth while chewing food. I'm not sure what the etiquette is in these situations.[qr

dictionary.entry: eucalyptus /\times,0\juklyptus is a tall, evergreen tree which is native to Australia. There are many different varieties, and some of them are used for their timber and the oil in their leaves. They are also commonly known as gum trees.

form.definition: noun Euthanasia is bringing about the death of a person who is suffering from a terminal illness and who wishes to die. He was an enthusiastic supporter of voluntary euthanasia.

verb If people evacuate a place, they move out of it for a period of time because it would be dangerous to stay, for example because of war or a natural disaster. Everybody had to evacuate their homes before the floods arrived. The building had to be evacuated because of a bomb scare. Australian tourists are being evacuated from the zone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun evacuation

form.definition: verb If you evade something, you avoid it or escape it, often by a trick. Felix had many schemes for evading tax, but they finally caught up with him. The rat evaded capture by hiding in a hollow log. We can't evade these unpleasant truths.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun evasion Tax evasion is illegal. Her answers were full of lies and evasions.adjective evasive The pilot was forced to take evasive action. She gave an evasive answer.

form.definition: verb If you evaluate something, you consider it carefully to decide how good or useful it is. Your work will be evaluated each term. The effect of the new law has not yet been evaluated. All the proposals will be evaluated and the best one chosen.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun evaluation We would welcome your evaluation of the training course.

form.definition: verb If a liquid evaporates, it changes to vapour as it becomes hotter.

verb You can also use evaporate to mean that something disappears, leaving nothing behind. When I saw him again, my anger evaporated. I had $500 last month, but with all these bills it's just evaporated.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun evaporation

form.definition: noun In slightly old-fashioned language, the eve of an event is the day or time immediately before it. They got married on the eve of his departure. The government announced a package of tax cuts on the eve of the election. ...New Year's Eve.
adjective If something is even, it is level or smooth. This area isn't even enough for a tennis court. Be sure to work on an even surface.

adjective If something is even, it is about the same all over or all the time. There are no big differences or changes. Spread the icing in an even layer. Try to hit the ball with an even, controlled movement. I'm glad to say he has a very even temper. Trim the stalks to an even length.
adjective If two things are even, they are equal or the same. Add a few more to this pile, to make them even. 'Do these two plates look even to you?' 'No, that one's darker.'

adjective If two people are even, they are in the same situation. Neither of them has an advantage over the other. We each came top in one of the papers, so we're even. You bought the wine, so if I pay for the meal we'll be even. She vowed to get even with her rival.
adjective If a contest or conflict is even, it is equally balanced or fairly matched. It should be a fairly even match.
adjective An even number can be divided by 2, with nothing left over. The even numbers are 2, 4, 6, 8 and so on.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is odd.

form.definition: verb If you even something, you make it equal or balanced. Jan evened the score with a last-minute goal.

adverb If you want to emphasise something that you find surprising, you can put even before it. Even Jo dislikes her. He didn't even say thank you. I can't even boil an egg. Can't you even try to help? Even after that, he loved her.

adverb If you say that something is even better or even longer or even more difficult than something else, you mean it is still more so. They say it'll be even hotter tomorrow. Gina's good-looking, but her sister's even more beautiful.

even if You use even if to emphasise that although something may happen or may be true, it doesn't make any difference. Even if we leave now, we'll still be late. He should still be polite, even if he is your boss. I couldn't help you, even if I wanted to. Please reply, even if you can't attend.
even out If something evens out, it becomes fair or equal. We take it in turns to buy groceries, and it all evens out in the end. Their scores evened out as the tests continued.
even so You use even so (in the main clause) to emphasise that although something is the case, it doesn't make any difference. It was an accident, but even so he should still have apologised.

even though You use even though (in the subordinate clause) to emphasise that although something is the case, it doesn't make any difference. Even though it was an accident, he should still apologise. They let me in, even though I hadn't got my pass.
even up If you even something up, you make it fair or equal. Let's even things upyou bought the tickets, so I'll pay for the meal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb evenly Spread the paste evenly. Try to brake more evenly. I divided it evenly.

form.definition: noun The evening is the period between about 6 p.m. and about midnight, when people commonly have free time for entertainment. Did you see that program on SBS yesterday evening? I'm not usually at home in the evening. I'll try and arrive by the early evening. I love these warm summer evenings.
good evening In formal situations, you can say good evening to greet someone. Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.
this evening When you say this evening, you mean the evening of today. I'm seeing my mother this evening.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective evening What time do you have your evening meal. I like to go for an evening stroll.

form.definition: noun An evening class is an educational course that is held in the evenings so that people who work during the day can attend it. I'm doing an evening class in word processing. She studied Japanese at evening class.

Evening dress is very formal clothes that people sometimes wear to very grand parties or to events such as the opera. It consists of a black suit and bow tie for men and usually a long dress for women.

noun An event is something that happens. The program reports and analyses current events. She reflected on the day's events. That was one of the most important events in my life. The party was quite an event!
noun A sporting event is a race or competition or match. Tom's running in five events at the school sports day.
in any event If you say something will happen in any event, you mean that it will definitely happen, no matter what else does. We may not get divorced, but in any event we're separating.
in the event of You say in the event of when you are talking about what to do if a particular thing does happen. In the event of fire, do not use the lifts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective eventful It's been quite an eventful week!

form.definition: adverb If something happens eventually, it happens in the end, or after a long time. I'm just starting to learn the trade, but eventually I'd like to run my own business.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective eventual The eventual outcome of the scandal was that he resigned his portfolio.

form.definition: adverb Ever means 'at any time'. Have you ever been to Cairns? Do you ever see Chris these days? Don't ever come here again. I miss him more than ever. Hamish got the best score ever.
ever since Ever since means during all the time between when something happened and now. I turned down the offer, and I've regretted it ever since. I've hated her ever since I first met her.
noun An evergreen is a tree or bush that has green leaves all year round. The garden is always shady because of the evergreens.

determiner Every refers to each single person or thing without any exceptions. Every child's hearing is tested in kindergarten. He lost every cent he had. Every time I go to Canberra, I visit my mother. Ali gets stronger every week. I see her every day.
determiner Every is also used for emphasis, to show that you are sure about something. I have every confidence in his ability. The plan has every chance of success.
form.note: ... NOTEthat every is used with a singular noun.

form.definition: every so often Something that happens every so often occurs occasionally. I still see him every so often. Every so often, I really feel like an ice-cream.
pronoun Everybody means the same as everyone.
adjective If something is described as everyday, it is ordinary or normal. Don't get dressed upjust wear your everyday clothes. It's nice to take a break from the everyday routine.
adjective If something is an everyday event, it happens very often and there is nothing special about it. Performing in public is an everyday experience for her.

pronoun Everyone means all the people concerned. Everyone has to eat to live. Everyone in the room laughed. I thought everyone knew Rose and Ted had split up. Do you know everyone here? You can't please everyone.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is everybody.

form.definition: pronoun Everything means all the things concerned, or the whole situation. Everything is part of the universe. Have you packed everything in the car? I think everything's under control. I can't handle everything myself. Everything's going wrong.

adverb Everywhere means 'in all places' or 'to all places'. God is everywhere. I've looked everywhere, but I still can't find my keys. Europe, AmericaSally seems to have been everywhere. He goes everywhere by car.
verb If someone evicts you, they force you by law to leave a place such as a house or flat that you are occupying. The new landlord got a court order to have us evicted.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun eviction

form.definition: noun Evidence is a clear indication or sign of something. Your high blood pressure and stomach ulcer are evidence that you're under too much stress.

noun Evidence is the information that is used in a law court to prove or disprove a case. The police reckon there's enough evidence to convict him. The victim's evidence was very convincing. Who's next to give evidence?

adjective If something is evident, it is clear or obvious. Her displeasure was evident. His evident enjoyment made it all worthwhile. It's evident that we still have much work to do. It's not yet evident whether they'll succeed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb evidently She evidently got there before us. You've met George before, evidently.

form.definition: adjective If something is evil, it is morally very bad. What drives people to commit these evil crimes?
adjective If someone is evil, they are wicked and do great harm deliberately.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is evil, you mean it is unpleasant or bad. What's that evil smell? His homemade wine is an evil brew.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun evil His heart was filled with evil. Cars are one of the evils of modern living.adverb evilly The mad professor laughed evilly. The liquid bubbled evilly in the flask.

form.definition: noun Evolution is steady gradual change and development. She's studying the evolution of ideas about language.
noun In particular, evolution refers to the idea that gradual change over generations leads to new species of animals and plants. Some thinkers still refuse to accept evolution.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb evolve The plan evolved over two years. Human beings have evolved from the apes.

form.definition: prefix meaning 'former' or 'old', as in ex-wife, ex-husband.
form.note: ... NOTE that this is sometimes used as an abbreviation for the full form: I haven't heard from my ex for ages.

form.definition: adjective If something is exact, it is correct or accurate in every detail. Her wedding dress was an exact copy of her grandmother's. The measurements must be exact, or the cupboards won't fit. EXACT FARE ONLY: NO CHANGE GIVEN

adjective If you quote an exact figure or someone's exact words, you state the figure or words precisely. I can't remember the exact date, but it was some time in July. Her exact words were 'drop dead, fatso!'.

verb If you exact something from someone, you get it from them, often by force, although they are reluctant to give it to you. The gangs exact protection money from most of the local businesses. She managed to exact a substantial settlement from her ex-husband.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb See exactly.

form.definition: adverb Exactly means 'precisely'. He arrived at exactly ten o'clock. I've got exactly $12 left. It's exactly a year ago today that I first met him. That's $8 exactly, please. They're both exactly the same.

adverb You also use exactly to show that you agree with someone, especially when they're talking about how they feel about something. 'He could have done more to help.' 'Exactly.' 'I wouldn't mind so much if she'd only apologise.' 'Exactly so.'

verb If you exaggerate, you say something is better, or worse, or bigger, and so on, than it really is. You can't believe Shurashe always exaggerates. I'm not exaggeratingthe fish was huge. He exaggerated the pain to get more compensation. I exaggerated the story for effect.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun exaggeration He's given to exaggeration. It would be no exaggeration to call her a hero.

form.definition: noun An exam is a test of your knowledge or skill in a particular subject. It can be written, oral or practical. My maths exam is on Friday.
form.note: ... NOTEThis is a shortened form of examination.

form.definition: noun An examination is a formal word for an exam.

noun If a doctor carries out a medical examination on you, they assess you carefully to see if you are healthy, or to diagnose any illness. The fee for the examination includes X-rays, a blood test and a urine test.

noun If you make an examination of something, you look at it carefully, especially to find any problems or faults. My examination of the book revealed a cracked spine. On closer examination, it turned out not to be a spider. The plan will be subject to further examination by the committee.

verb If you examine something, you look at it carefully, especially to find any problems or faults. She examined the book thoroughly before she bought it. We must examine the plan in detail before making any decision.
verb When a doctor examines a patient, they assess them carefully to diagnose any illness.
verb If someone examines you on a particular subject, they ask you questions about it to see how much you know. We're only being examined on the first five chapters of the textbook.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See examination.noun examiner The examiners asked some difficult questions in the test.

form.definition: noun An example of something is one thing that represents others of the same kind. You mention it to show the kind of thing you are talking about. 'Girl' and 'goodness' are examples of nouns. Could you give us an example of what you mean?

noun An example is something which shows you the best way to do something. It is a model that you should imitate. Meryem's courage through this difficult time is an example to the rest of us. The first problem has been done for you as an example.

for example You use for example to indicate that you are giving one or more examples of what you are talking about, that there are other things of the same kind that you do not name. There are many courses available for migrantsfor example, English for Small Business.

make an example of If you make an example of someone, you punish them severely for something wrong they have done. You do this to warn others, so that they will not make the same mistake. The principal decided to make an example of Nino to deter other students from stealing.

verb If something exasperates you, it irritates and annoys you a great deal. Susy really exasperates meshe simply will not keep her room tidy! By the time the bus finally arrived, I was absolutely exasperated. Their behaviour is exasperating.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun exasperation I couldn't hide my exasperation.

form.definition: verb If you excavate something, you hollow it out or remove the inner part. You scoop out a hole or a tunnel. Builders are still excavating the site to lay the foundations. Excavating under Sydney Harbour for the tunnel was a major engineering feat.
verb If something exceeds something else, it is greater or better than it. The total bill should not exceed $5O. My examination results exceeded my expectations.
verb If you exceed something, you go beyond what is legal or allowed. The police booked him for exceeding the speed limit. IT IS DANGEROUS TO EXCEED THE STATED DOSE
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See excess.adverb exceedingly This is an exceedingly good vintage.

form.definition: verb If you excel at something, you are very good at it. Tim excelled in his mid-year exams. She excels as a distance runner.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See excellent.

form.definition: adjective If something is excellent, it is extremely good. The food at the restaurant was excellent. She achieved excellent production results.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun excellence

form.definition: preposition If you make a statement about everything except one thing, then that thing is the only one that your statement doesn't apply to. It is an exception to what you say. All the family was there except Manuel. I can come any day except Tuesday. I've read the whole book except the last chapter. I'm willing to do anything except beg.

conjunction You use except to describe a situation that is an exception to what you say. They can do anything they like, except I don't want them going in my bedroom. The girls look very similar, except Jenny's a bit shorter and her hair's darker.
conjunction You can use except to explain the reason why something doesn't happen. Sherri would have come with us, except she was training. I'd like to go out tonight, except I'm really tired.

except for You use except for to mention something that is an exception to what you say. All the family was there except for Manuel. Except for some rain on Friday, the weather has been superb. Except for Tom and Lara, everyone enjoyed the party.

noun An exception is something that doesn't follow the rule or general pattern that other things do. It is different from the rest. Most of us are 13, but Jan's an exceptionshe's 14. Without exception, they're a talented group. The rules apply to you all, with no exceptions. They refused to make an exception.

take exception to If you take exception to something, you object to it very strongly. You do not like it at all. What I take exception to is the way he never consults us. She took exception to my opening remarks.

with the exception of You use with the exception of to mention something to which what you say doesn't apply. All the family was there with the exception of Manuel. I passed all my courses with the exception of English.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See exceptional.

form.definition: adjective If something is exceptional, it is very different from normal. In view of the exceptional circumstances, we've extended the deadline. Rainfall in the area has been exceptional for the time of year.
adjective If something is exceptional, it is extremely good. It is much better than average. Her talent is truly exceptional.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb exceptionally

form.definition: noun The excess is an amount left over. It is more than what is needed or wanted. I still had two full cans of paint, so I took the excess back for a refund. Wipe away the excess with a damp cloth.

noun The excess on an insurance policy is the amount of a claim that you have to pay yourself. The insurance company will pay the amount that is more than this. The repair cost $750, but the excess was $200, so I only got $550. For a voluntary excess of $500, we offer a 10% discount on the premium.

in excess of In formal language, in excess of means 'more than'. The school has in excess of 800 pupils. Several villagers are in excess of 100 years old. The car was travelling in excess of 100 km/h.
to excess If you do something to excess, you do it too much. She drinks to excess. Exercise is good for you, as long as you don't take it to excess.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective excess I had to pay $300 for my excess baggage. Drain off the excess liquid.adjective excessive Showering three times a day seems excessive.

form.definition: verb If you exchange something, you replace it with something else. Carlos asked the salesperson if he could exchange the red tie for a black one. I need to exchange some more currency.

verb If you exchange things of the same type with someone else, you give them to each other. We exchanged business cards. The conference is a valuable opportunity to exchange ideas with colleagues. We exchanged seats after the interval.

noun An exchange is the act of giving something to someone else, who then gives you something back. I'll swap my biscuits for your appleis that a fair exchange? The shop doesn't allow exchanges without the original sales dockets. I went to Japan on a student exchange.
noun An exchange is also an argument or discussion. Tom and Sam had a heated exchange over who should take Rebecca to the school dance. We had a useful exchange about how to develop my ideas.

in exchange If you give someone something in exchange for something else, you trade with them. You both get something you want. I gave him a bottle of wine in exchange for his help. I'd like to offer you something in exchange.
verb If something excites you, it makes you feel very lively or interested. Don't excite the children just as they go to bed. Studying grammar doesn't really excite me.
adjective If you are excited, you feel very lively and interested. The excited children rushed about the house. I'm really excited about going to Bali next year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun excitement His excitement at going to Bali was obvious.

form.definition: adjective If something is exciting, it makes you feel very lively and interested. The children found the trip very exciting. The work experience was the most exciting part of the course. In an exciting development today, the minister resigned.
verb If you exclaim, you speak or cry out suddenly to express an emotion you feel. When she saw me, she exclaimed in surprise. The villain exclaimed in triumph. 'How extraordinary!', he exclaimed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See exclamation.

form.definition: noun An exclamation is something you say or cry out suddenly to express an emotion that you feel. The news was greeted with exclamations of surprise.

exclamation mark An exclamation mark ( ! ) is the written sign that you use after words expressing strong feeling, or to show that something is surprisingas in 'Shut up!', 'Good heavens!' or 'He ate seven pies!'

verb If you exclude someone, you leave them out of an activity or prevent them from doing something. The chairperson is usually excluded from voting. We must keep the price of admission low, so as not to exclude anyone.
verb If something excludes something else, it doesn't cover it. The holiday package excludes meals. The insurance policy excludes deliberate misuse.
verb If you exclude an idea or suggestion, you decide that it is not worth considering. We cannot exclude the possibility that he was murdered. So we've excluded raising our prices for this year?
excluding Excluding indicates that what you mention next is not included. It is left out. There were about forty people at the party, excluding the organisers.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is including. ... WORD FAMILYnoun exclusion There are a number of exclusions in the small print.

form.definition: adjective If something is exclusive, then it is for only one person or group of people. We have an exclusive arrangement with the manufacturer to distribute these products.
adjective If something is exclusive, it is expensive and not widely available. We sell a range of exclusive designer ornaments. They were spotted in one of Melbourne's most exclusive boutiques.
noun If a newspaper or magazine prints an exclusive, it is the only one to cover the story or be granted an interview.
exclusive of Exclusive of indicates that what you mention next is not included. It is left out. Tickets to the dance cost $50, exclusive of drinks.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb exclusively These courses are exclusively for recent migrants.

form.definition: verb Animals and humans excrete or pass out waste matter from their bodies.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun excrement

form.definition: adjective If something is excruciating, it is very unpleasant or painful. There followed a week of excruciating suspense. The pain was excruciating. I had to have a series of excruciating injections in the stomach.
noun An excursion is a short trip or journey that you make for a special reason. We arranged an excursion to the city to go shopping. Children go on school excursions every term.

dictionary.entry:
excuse@k`skju:s <for the noun; for the verb,>Ek`skju:z
noun An excuse is an explanation or reason why something doesn't happen as it should. He made some feeble excuse for being late. Being in a hurry is no excuse for rudeness. The meeting's a good excuse to stop work for an afternoon. I don't want to hear any excuses.
verb If you excuse someone, you forgive them for doing something wrong. I'll excuse you this time, but try not to be late again. People will readily excuse your errors in English if your meaning is clear.
verb If you ask someone to excuse you, you ask them to let you leave or not attend or not do something planned. Can you excuse me from the meeting? I've got an appointment at the dentist. You'll have to excuse me nowI've got a visitor coming.
excuse me (a) You say excuse me to attract someone's attention so that you can ask them a question or tell them something. Excuse meis there a post office near here? Excuse me, you've dropped your glove. Excuse me, professor, could you repeat that last point?
(b) You also say excuse me as an apology when you do something slightly rude or impolite, such as burping or bumping into someone or going into a room where they are doing something. Excuse me, I just want to collect my bag.
(c) You also say excuse me when you want to get past someone who's standing in your way, or when you have to push your way through somewhere that's crowded with people. (d) You also say excuse me when you want to contradict someone politely or assert your rights. Excuse me, but the meeting was actually on Monday. Excuse me, there's someone sitting there. Excuse me, it's my turn next.
... WORD FAMILYadjective excusable It was an excusable mistake to make.

form.definition: verb If someone is executed, they are put death as a punishment for a serious crime. Ronald Ryan was the last person to be executed in Australia. Thousands of the dictator's opponents were executed by death squads.
verb In formal language, if you execute something, you do it or carry it out as intended. She neatly executed a triple backward somersault. What resources will be needed to execute this plan?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See executive.noun executionnoun See executor.

form.definition: noun An executive is someone who holds a senior position in a company. The number of female executives in Australian companies is slowly rising.
noun An executive is a group of people who run or manage a company or other organisation. The union executive is meeting today.
noun An executor is someone who is named in a will to carry out the instructions in it. My aunt has asked me to be her executor.

adjective If you are exempt from some decision or regulation, you are not affected by it. The normal rules do not apply to you. Those over 65 are exempt from this requirement. Certain payments and allowances are exempt from tax.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun exemption She was granted an exemption from the application fee.

form.definition: noun Exercise is any physical activity that you do to keep fit. Sam never does any exercisethat's why he's so fat. I cycle to workthat's my only exercise. Have you been getting any exercise lately? A large dog needs a lot of exercise.

noun An exercise is a set of movements designed to use and develop a particular set of muscles. Let's warm up with some stretching exercises. I haven't been doing my exercises lately. The optometrist taught me some eye exercises. This is a good exercise for the leg muscles.

noun An exercise is a drill designed to practise and improve your skill in a particular activity. Please do the exercise on page 45. Sonia's doing her piano exercises. The army's holding exercises at the range next weekend.
verb If you exercise, you do some physical activity to keep fit. It's important to exercise regularly. Swimming exercises the arm muscles.
verb In formal language, if you exercise your power or your abilities, you use them. You must exercise caution when turning into a stream of traffic. He exercised his right to reply.

verb If you exert your influence or you exert pressure, you use them to try to change a situation. We are exerting what pressure we can for the decision to be reversed. His elder brother exerted a calming influence on him.

exert yourself If you exert yourself, you make a big effort. My back really hurtsI think I exerted myself too much playing tennis. You'll never pass your exams if you don't exert yourself. He didn't exactly exert himself to help us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun exertion The strenuous physical exertion tired me out. All her exertions were in vain.

form.definition: verb If you exhale, you breathe out. You let the air out of your lungs.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is inhale. ... WORD FAMILYnoun exhalation

form.definition: verb If something exhausts you, it makes you very tired, so that you have no energy left. The five sets of tennis completely exhausted me.

verb In formal language, if you exhaust something, you use it all up. We've exhausted the funds allocated to the project. Their quarrels have exhausted my patience. After six weeks at sea their supplies were exhausted.
noun The exhaust of a vehicle such as a car or a truck is the waste gases from the engine.

noun Exhaust also means the pipe or system on a car or truck through which the waste gases are released into the air. He killed himself with a tube attached to the exhaust. I had to have a whole new exhaust fitted.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective exhaust ...exhaust fumes.adjective See exhaustive.adjective exhausted I fell exhausted into bed. Her visits always leave me exhausted.adjective exhausting We went on an exhausting bushwalk. I'm finding this course really exhausting.noun exhaustion He was grey with exhaustion. Several runners were treated for exhaustion.

form.definition: adjective If something is exhaustive, it is very detailed or complete. This is not an exhaustive list of the possibilities. She made us listen to an exhaustive account of her travels.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with exhausting.

form.definition: verb If you exhibit something, you put it on display in a public place so that people can look at it. She's exhibiting her tapestries at a gallery in town. The corpses were exhibited at the crossroads as a warning to others. b noun An exhibit is something that is put on display, especially in a museum or an art gallery. There are several interactive exhibits to stimulate learning. The murder weapon was produced in court as an exhibit.

verb In rather formal language, if you exhibit a particular quality, you display it. You act in that way. When crossed, she can exhibit a nasty temper. He exhibited remarkable patience in answering my questions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun exhibition

form.definition: noun If someone is in exile, they are forced to live away from their home or country, usually for political reasons. He returned home in triumph after ten years of exile. The rebels established a government in exile.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb exile She was exiled for writing against the regime.

form.definition: verb If something exists, it is alive or is present as a real thing. When did dinosaurs exist? I was shocked to discover that such conditions exist. The diary still exists, and is in the city library.
verb If someone exists, they only just manage to survive in very difficult conditions. They exist on a single bowl of rice each day. You can't call it livingit's just existing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun existence How did the world come into existence? He leads a miserable existence.adjective existing The book sets out the existing rules and the proposed changes.

form.definition: noun An exit is a way out. It can be something like a door, a corridor or a driveway. The exits must remain clear at all times. There are emergency exits located over each wing. Take the next exit for Gosford.
make an exit If you make an exit, you leave. I gave my opinion and made a quick exit rather than get drawn into discussion. We'll stay half an hour to be polite, and then make our exit.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb exit To exit the program, press 'Q' for 'quit'.

form.definition: noun An exodus is a lot of people leaving a place at the same time. We got caught up in the Friday evening exodus from the city. The new teacher caused a mass exodus of students from the course.

adjective If something is exotic, it is unusual or interesting because it is outside your usual experience. She's always going on exotic overseas holidays. He bought an exotic embroidered shirt. AVAILABLE IN SEVEN EXOTIC FLAVOURS The kitchen was full of exotic smells.
adjective An exotic plant is one that has been introduced from outside Australia.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is native.

form.definition: verb If something expands, it becomes larger or spreads out. The tyre expands as you pump air into it. Metals expand as they are heated. Can you expand the ring to fit this finger? We want to expand our business overseas.
expand on If you expand on something, you talk or write about it in more detail. Could you expand on your point about the extra costs?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun expansion

form.definition: noun An expanse of something is a large area of it. We saw huge expanses of desert when we drove in the Northern Territory.
verb If you expect that something will happen, you think it is likely that it will happen. I expect it'll rain later. I didn't expect to be so lucky. The prime minister is expected to resign today.

verb If you expect someone or something, you think that they will arrive soon. What time do you expect your husband? I'm expecting a letter from my sister. Is anyone here expecting a parcel? I'm expecting an important phone call.

verb If you expect someone to do something, you want them to do it. You have authority over them, and you assume that they will do what you want. I expect you to behave properly this afternoon. All our pupils are expected to wear the correct uniform.

verb If you say that a woman is expecting, you mean that she is pregnant. She is going to have a baby. ... WORD FAMILYadjective expectant ...the expectant look on the children's faces. ...an expectant mother.noun expectation The results have exceeded expectations. It's hard to live up to expectations.
noun An expedition is a trip or journey made for a specific reason. She took part in a scientific expedition to the South Pole. The expedition leaves Hobart early in January.
verb If you expel someone from somewhere, you order them to leave. The principal expelled two pupils for stealing from the local video shop. Many supporters of the previous regime were expelled.
verb If you expel something from somewhere, you push it out by force. The jet of air expelled the obstruction from the pipe.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See expulsion.

form.definition: verb In fairly formal language, if you expend something, you spend it or use it up. We've already expended $10 000 on the project. You expend a lot of energy just keeping warm. I expended a lot of effort on planning the party.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See expense.

form.definition: noun Expenditure is the amount of money you spend. We need to reduce our expenditure on salaries. The company must keep a record of all income and expenditure.

noun An expense is a cost. It is an amount of money that you have to pay for something. I've had a lot of extra expenses this month. My dental expenses came to over $1000 last year. You can claim many business expenses against tax.
at someone's expense (a) If you do something at someone's expense, they bear the cost. They pay for it. I hope to go on an overseas trip at my company's expense.
(b) If you do something at someone's expense, they suffer because of it. The others were making jokes at Ivan's expense. Her style is very concise, sometimes at the expense of clarity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See expensive.

form.definition: adjective If something is expensive, it costs a lot of money. Medical insurance can be very expensive. ... THE OPPOSITE of this is inexpensive. ... WORD FAMILYadverb expensively She's always very expensively dressed.
verb If you experience something, it happens to you. He's already experienced great suffering in his young life. I experienced difficulty in breathing.
noun An experience is something that happens to you. I had an unusual experience on my way to work today. The holiday was an unforgettable experience.

noun Your experience in a particular job or activity is the amount of time you have spent doing it, and the amount of knowledge and skill you have gained. Have you any retail experience? I have twenty years' experience as a restaurant manager. We need someone with more experience. KITCHEN STAFF NEEDED URGENTLYNO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective experienced She's an experienced chef.

form.definition: noun An experiment is a scientific test carried out to support or disprove a theory or idea. What experiment can we do to test this idea?

noun An experiment is also a test of a new method, idea or plan to see if it will be successful. I've used a new recipe as an experimentI hope the soup tastes OK. The policy seems to be designed as a social experiment.
3 verb If you experiment, you try out new ways of doing something. Experiment with a few different colour schemes until you find one that you like.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective experimental The plan is still in the experimental stages.

form.definition: noun An expert is someone who is very skilled and experienced at doing something. John's our computer expert. Marilyn's a real expert at bridge.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun expertise She skis with great expertise. We need to call on your expertise.

form.definition: verb If something expires, it reaches the date when it is due to finish. It is not able to be used any longer. My bus pass expired on Tuesday. Check whether the use-by date has expired before using the milk. The time limit for bringing a case is about to expire.
verb In formal language, if you say that someone expires, you mean that they die. The animals expired in the severe heat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun expiry What's the date of expiry of your passport?

form.definition: verb If you explain something, you talk about it to make someone understand what it is or how it works. The official explained the regulations to us. Could you explain the problem to me again? The book explains all you need to know.
verb If you explain something, you give reasons for it. I can't explain why the computer isn't working. Why are you so late? Please explain yourself. What are the factors that explain this change?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun explanation Ann gave a good explanation of the word. His explanation was unconvincing.

form.definition: noun An expletive is a strong and sometimes rude exclamation, such as 'damn!' or 'shit!', that someone says when they are angry, frustrated or bitter. He let loose a string of expletives when he hit his thumb with the hammer.
verb If something explodes, it blows up or bursts into pieces with a loud noise. The bomb was about to explode. The gas cylinder exploded and caused great destruction.
verb If someone explodes, they suddenly express their anger or some other strong feeling. She exploded with anger and frustration when she read the bad report.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See explosion.noun See explosive.

dictionary.entry:
exploit@k`spl@:It <for the verb; for the noun,>`Ekspl@:It
verb If someone exploits you, they take advantage of you or treat you unfairly because you are not able to assert your rights. Many employers exploit migrant workers by illegally paying them below-award wages. Andrew exploits Sally's good nature by getting her to run errands for him.
verb If you exploit something such as a natural resource, you develop it in order to make money out of it. The gold mines were first fully exploited in the nineteenth century.
noun An exploit is a brave deed or a daring act. She's making a documentary about the exploits of early aviators. He entertained us all with tales of his exploits in Asia. ... WORD FAMILYadjective exploitative They work under exploitative conditions.noun exploitation The managers are guilty of ruthless exploitation.

form.definition: verb If you explore an area, you travel all over it to find out about it. Ludwig Leichhardt was one of the first to explore the Australian interior. They're exploring off the coast for gas and oil.

verb If you explore an idea or a topic, you think about it carefully or discuss it in detail. Let's explore the options for increasing our revenue. In this article she explores the influences on Henry Lawson's writing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun exploration ...a voyage of exploration. The idea merits further exploration.noun explorer The explorer John Stuart crossed Australia from south to north in 1862.

form.definition: noun An explosion is a sudden loud and destructive burst of energy. It is what happens when something explodes. We heard the explosion from several blocks away.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See explode.

form.definition: noun An explosive is a substance or device that can explode.
adjective If something is explosive, it is likely to explode. Police found explosive materials in the suspect's house.
adjective You can say that something is explosive if it happens suddenly and with a loud noise. Max has an explosive temper.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See explode.

form.definition: verb If you export a product, you send it overseas to someone who has bought it from you. Last year our company exported over $1 000 000 worth of finished goods. In order to grow, we'll have to export.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is import. ... WORD FAMILY Australian exports include wheat, wool, lamb, beef, coal and uranium.

form.definition: verb If you expose something, you uncover or reveal it. You allow something that was hidden to be seen or known. We stripped the paint off the door to expose the natural wood. He was exposed as a fraud.

verb If you expose someone to something, you allow them to have contact with it. The children were exposed to German measles last weekI hope they don't come down with it. Hanni's reckless driving exposed us all to danger.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective exposed The house stands near the cliff, in a very windy, exposed position.noun See exposure.

form.definition: noun Exposure is the amount of light or sun that reaches something. Very fair skin can burn after just ten minutes' exposure to the sun. What exposure did you use for this photograph? We want a house with a northern exposure.
noun If you're suffering from exposure, you have been out in the sun, wind, snow or rain for too long and become ill as a result. The lost hikers were suffering from exposure when they were found.
noun Exposure is also publicity, when something is discussed a lot in the media. Their affair has received much press exposure.

verb If you express an idea or opinion or feeling, you put it into words. She wrote to express support for the project. I can't express how grateful I am. He finds it hard to express his emotions. I'm not expressing it very welllet me try again.

verb You can also express a feeling or thought by your behaviour or the look on your face. He expressed his disapproval by walking out of the room. This gift is to express my gratitude for all your help.

adjective Express services are performed faster or sooner than regular services, often for a higher price. I sent the letter by express mail. We offer an express photo service. b adjective An express train goes from one main station to another without stopping at many stations in between.

adjective Something express is clear, definite and specific. There can be no misunderstanding or mistake. My express orders were to stay inside and not to answer the door. Why did you disregard my express instructions. Her express purpose was to cause trouble.

express yourself When you express yourself, you communicate your thoughts or feelings. I can't express myself very well in English. We encourage patients to express themselves through drama and dance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See expression.adjective expressive She's got a very expressive face.

form.definition: noun An expression is a look on someone's face that shows how they are feeling. Her expression changed from surprise to anger. He wore a puzzled expression.
2a noun An expression is words that are used together with a particular meaning. What does the expression 'to put on airs' mean? She uses a lot of British expressions I don't understand.
noun An expression of disgust or of anger or of some other emotion is something that someone says or exclaims to show how they feel. The news was greeted with expressions of delight.

noun Expression is also how you show your thoughts or feelings, in words or some other form. The ideas in your essay are good, but the expression could be clearer. She puts a great deal of expression into her playing. They claimed the right to artistic expression.
noun An expressway is a wide road that is built for a lot of high speed traffic. ...a three-lane expressway.
noun An expulsion is a situation where someone is expelled from a school or a country. Paola's expulsion for selling drugs shocked her family. The new regime ordered mass expulsions of dissidents.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See expel.

form.definition: adjective If something is exquisite, it is very carefully made and lovely. There is some exquisite silverware in the museum. She served the most exquisite pork dumplings. Look at the exquisite drawing in these miniatures. It's an exquisite pale blue.
verb If something extends over a certain distance, it reaches or goes that far. The park extends right down to the river. Her knowledge of computers extends well beyond mine.

verb If you extend something, you stretch it out as far as it will go. Extend the rope between these two posts. When fully extended, a python can measure up to eight metres. The more able students need activities to extend them.

verb If you extend something, you make it bigger or more inclusive. We're extending our house with another bedroom and bathroom. Shopping hours have been extended for Christmas trading. These arrangements will be extended to cover the whole city.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See extension.adjective See extensive.noun See extent.

form.definition: noun An extension is an extra part added to a building. The twins can sleep in the extension when they come to stay. We're having extensions done.
noun An extension is an extra telephone connected to a main line. You can call me on extension 8735. Shona was listening in on the extension.
adjective If something is extensive, it covers a large area. The national park contains extensive areas of rain forest.

adjective If something is extensive, it is great and wide-ranging. The car suffered extensive damage. I have extensive experience of bookkeeping. Extensive enquiries have failed to locate her. They presented an extensive list of demands.
noun The extent of something is its full size or amount. The forest is several hundred hectares in extent. We don't yet know the extent of the damage. The benefits are very limited in extent.

to an extent If you say that something is true or possible to an extent or to a certain extent, you mean that it is partly true or possible. To a certain extent I agree with you. That's true to an extent, but it's not the whole story. To what extent do you attribute your success to luck?

adjective Something exterior is out of doors, or on the outside of something. I painted all the exterior woodwork of the house. We've just got a few more exterior scenes to film. The exterior surface was badly worn.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is interior. ... WORD FAMILYnoun exterior Repaint the exterior every ten years. Under his grim exterior, he's very nice.

form.definition: verb If you exterminate pests, you kill them and get rid of them entirely. What can we do to exterminate the cockroaches in the kitchen?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun extermination noun exterminator We'd better call in an exterminator.

form.definition: adjective Something external is outside something, or on the outer part of it. A lot of heat loss takes place through the external walls.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is internal.

form.definition: adjective If a cream or ointment is for external use, you are supposed to rub it into your skin.
adjective If you do external studies, you study from notes and tapes provided by a university for you to use at home. Andrew did an external arts degree through the University of New England.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is internal.

form.definition: adjective If a type of animal or plant is extinct, there are no longer any of them alive. The Tasmanian tiger is believed to be extinct.
adjective If a volcano is extinct, it is no longer active.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun extinction

form.definition: verb If you extinguish a fire, you put it out. You stop it burning. Firefighters struggled to extinguish the blaze.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun extinguisher The blue extinguisher is filled with foamyou can use it on petrol fires.

form.definition: noun Extortion is what happens when someone makes someone else give them money by using threats. The Mafia practises extortion on a huge scale.
noun In informal language, if you say that something is extortion, you mean that someone is taking advantage of a situation to charge unfairly high prices. $5 for a can of drinkit's sheer extortion!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb extort The gang extorted cash from local business people.adjective extortionate Their prices are extortionate.

form.definition: adjective If something is extra, it is more than there is already, or more than usual, or more than the minimum. We had to take on extra staff to meet the deadline. I earned an extra $60 last week. I've got an extra ticket for the moviewould you like it? Pack an extra jumper just in case.

adverb If something costs extra, it costs more than the basic price. Bread costs a dollar extra. You have to pay extra for the metallic finish. Is delivery included or extra? How much extra do I owe you?

noun An extra is something special that is added to the basic item and usually costs more. Extras commonly available on cars include tape decks, air conditioning and sun roofs. I ordered a hamburger with all the extras.
noun An extra is also someone with a very small part in a show or movie. The battle scenes involved thousands of extras.

dictionary.entry:
extract@k`strAkt <for the verb; for the noun,>
verb If you extract something from somewhere, you remove it. The dentist extracted four of my teeth. She used tweezers to extract the splinter.
noun An extract is a concentrated substance that is obtained from a natural product. The soap contains an extract of tea-tree oil. Add a spoonful of beef extract.
noun An extract is also a short passage from a book or other composition which is used as an example. Extracts from the biography were published in several newspapers.
... WORD FAMILYnoun extraction

form.definition: adjective If something is extraordinary, it is remarkable or surprising. What an extraordinary coincidence! She has extraordinary talent. He was wearing the most extraordinary outfit. I found her reaction quite extraordinary.
adjective An extraordinary meeting is held in addition to regular meetings, in order to discuss some unforeseen situation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb extraordinarily She's extraordinarily talented.

form.definition: adjective If someone is extravagant, they spend too much money or they are wasteful. You can't be extravagant on a pension. Don't be too extravagant with the milkit's got to last until Tuesday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun extravagance You're going to have to curb your extravagance.

form.definition: adjective If something is extreme, it is very great. She was in extreme pain. He grew up in extreme poverty. It was a time of extreme excitement for me. Her anguish was extreme.

adjective If something is extreme, it is very exaggerated. When she's been drinking, her behaviour becomes extreme. He's always so extremeit's either love or hate, nothing between. She wanted to run away, but I urged her not to be so extreme.
adjective The extreme point of something is the point furthest from the centre of attention. Joan is on the extreme left of the picture. They live in the extreme north of Queensland.
noun An extreme is something very exaggerated. Why does she take everything to such extremes? The paint is formulated to cope with extremes of temperature.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb extremely I'm extremely pleased to see you. He was extremely angry.noun See extremism.

form.definition: noun If you hold extreme opinions, especially on political issues, you can be accused of extremism. He was criticised for his extremism in demanding complete independence.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun extremist

form.definition: noun Your eyes are the parts of your body with which you see.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: verb If you eye something, you look at it closely or keenly, often because you want it. She was eyeing the cakes in the shop window.
have an eye for If you have an eye for something, you are able to judge it well. Masha has a good eye for colour. Pete always has an eye for a bargain.

keep an eye on If you keep an eye on something, you watch or monitor it carefully to make sure no harm comes to it or because of it. Can you keep an eye on my bag for a minute? You need to keep an eye on Adamhe can be real trouble. Keep an eye on the pressure to avoid damaging the tyres.

keep an eye out If you keep an eye out, you are watchful and vigilant in case you are able to find something. I've been keeping an eye out for a good second-hand heater. 'Have you seen Simon today?' 'No, but I'll keep an eye out.'
keep your eyes open If you keep your eyes open, you remain alert and watch carefully. Keep your eyes openit's around here somewhere.
open someone's eyes If something thing. The program really opened my eyes to the problems that migrants face.
see eye to eye If you see eye to eye with someone, you think the same way as they do. You agree with them. Margaret and I see eye to eye on this. I don't think we'll ever see eye to eye.
noun Your eyebrows are the arches of hair above your eyes.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTURE at body.

form.definition: noun Your eyelashes are the rows of hairs on the edge of your eyelids. ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.
noun Your eyelids are the folds of skin which cover your eyes when you close them.
noun Your eyesight is your ability to see. The optician checked my eyesight.
noun If you say something is an eyesore, you mean it is very ugly or unpleasant to look at. The new shopping mall is a real eyesore.
noun An eyewitness is someone who sees something such as a crime or accident happen.[fa[xp
